awd_abstract_narration:
In analogy to the fundamental role that random numbers play in classical information theory, random quantum states and unitary operators are a key resource in quantum information science. Unfortunately, generating a random unitary transformation is intractably inefficient, motivating the investigation of a weaker notion of quantum pseudorandomness that may be achieved efficiently while remaining practically useful.  In this program, fundamental properties and implications of quantum pseudorandomness will be explored from a mathematical, information-theoretic, and physical standpoint, by focusing on the generation of pseudorandomness using so-called random quantum circuits. Primary emphasis will be placed on (i) characterizing the behavior of random circuits under more general conditions than considered thus far; and (ii) performing a dedicated study of the effect of implementation errors and decoherence.  In doing so, the bigger goal of understanding whether random quantum circuits may serve to model the dynamics of generic many-body quantum systems will be kept in mind, with anticipated connections to the field of quantum chaos.

The scientific impact of this program will be twofold.  First, a substantially improved understanding of the complexity involved in generating pseudorandom states and operators using random quantum circuits is expected to emerge.  Beside providing a firm theoretical foundation for quantum information protocols that presume randomness as a resource, this could eventually find application in enhanced quantum algorithm design. Second, additional fundamental insights will also be gained on the emergence and characterization of apparent randomness in the properties of complex quantum systems.  Intensive training on subjects at the cross-disciplinary boundary between quantum information theory, applied mathematics, and many-body physics will be provided to the graduate student supported by this grant.

por.por_cntn:
Just like "randomness" is often regarded as a hallmark of "complexity" and "irreversibility" in everyday life phenomena, and random numbers play a crucial role in classical information theory and computer science, quantum-mechanical analogues of random numbers -- that is, random quantum states and random quantum dynamics -- are equally fundamental in quantum information processing theory. Important applications range from constructing protocols for quantum cryptography or scalable noise estimation in open quantum systems, to modeling the dynamics by which "typical" many-body quantum systems approach their equilibrium state in the long-time limit. 

The broad goal of this project has been the exploration of fundamental aspects and implications of randomness in the quantum world from a combined mathematical, information-theoretic, and physical standpoint -- including weaker but practically achievable notions of quantum "pseudo-randomness". Loosely speaking, a pseudo-random quantum state may be obtained as the output of a quantum circuit acting on quantum bits ("qubits"), where at each time step suitable logic transformations or "quantum gates" are effected at random on at most two such qubits -- as long as sufficiently many such gates are applied.

A number of outcomes have emerged as a result of the investigations supported by this award over its duration -- as summarized in a total of five research articles published to date. Especially worth highlighting are mathematically rigorous conditions describing the long-time convergence properties of a class of irreversible quantum dynamics to its unique equilibrium (or "steady") state, subject to the practical constraint that only a few quantum subsystems (for example, at most two qubits in the simplest case) are affected non-trivially by the dynamics at any given time. Building on these results, it has been possible to show, in particular, that random quantum states may or may not meet the conditions making them unique equilibrium states, depending on the dimensionality of the subsystems involved. Further to that, a class of dissipative quantum circuits, more general than random quantum circuits considered thus far, has been identified, allowing for exact convergence to a desired quantum state to occur in a finite time.  Altogether, the results emerged from this project have thus contributed to advance the cross-disciplinary knowledge frontier of complex quantum dynamics. 

In addition to its intellectual merit, the project has throughout incorporated strong educational and outreach components. A total of two undergraduate and two graduate students, plus two postdoctoral fellows have been engaged in research supported by this award and have been directly supervised by the principal investigator at different stages, with two of these talented individuals being women. All the students and postdocs have received intensive training on subjects at the boundary between quantum information theory, applied mathematics, and many-body physics, making them well-prepared for the increasingly cross-disciplinary demands of today's careers in science and technology. The principal investigator has further contributed to disseminate knowledge and generate excitement in quantum information science - and science more generally - by delivering both technical and nontechnical presentations at conferences and universities, as well as teaching dedicated courses at the undergraduate and graduate level.
